in the dawn of one of the first version

source code control system the
architecture of the tool consisted of
three different parts
a delta table control and tracking flags
and a set of control records
the delta table as you might expect is a
table that stores
each of the changes made to a file
control and tracking flags were used to
set permissions and control releases
and control records were used to keep
track of when lines of code
were deleted or inserted into a file by
storing those insertions
and deletions into special records in
this way
this version control system pioneered
some of the early principles
that we'll come to see in later version
control systems
sccs as it was known was popular until
year
1982 when its successor revision control
system
came to prominence the rcs system was
not distributed at all
so it wasn't possible to store copies of

central server
or another machine multiple people
couldn't edit the same file at the same
time so
merge conflicts weren't really a thing
that happened
i had one simple job store different
versions of code
next will travel to 1990 in the release
of the concurrent version system
commonly known as cvs unlike rcs
cvs employed a client server model a
copy of the repository was stored on a
central server
and several clients could make copies of
it at this point in time it was possible
for multiple people to be editing the
same file
so it was possible for two individuals
to make conflicting changes
to work around this issue cvs required
that you fetch
and merge the latest changes from the

before making any commits finally
we'll travel a little over a decade ago
to the year 2005

objects in the get context consist of a

there are four types of objects
blobs objects that are used to store

the time stamp on which a commit was

when we merge we keep an explicit
